page.title: 01Brimham to Eavestone
page.content: Brimham rocks (301m) is the highest point in this section, Eavestone Lake set in a narrow wooded green one of the lowest. Between them is High Moor, 500 acres of planted softwood forest. Streams rise here and flow to the skell and S to the Nidd. The area is sparsely populated. A dozen scattered farms and the hamlet of fell beck account for the resident population. One permanent & two or three occasional use caravan sites accommodate people who come to enjoy the beauty & recreational aspects of the National Trust property of Brimham Rocks, known for weathered grit rocks & moorland scenery. The farms are mixed. Sheep roam the moors. Pigs, beef & dairy cattle are kept. Pheasants are reared for shooting. The RAF makes shattering use of the air space for training flights & low
